hints.content:
We can solve this question by determining the percent change in David's height from his fourth birthday to his eighth birthday. 

David's height was $40$ inches on his fourth birthday and $50$ inches on his eighth birthday, which means his height increased by $50-40=10$ inches.

The change in height is compared to his starting height, $40$ inches:

$\begin{align}
\text{percent change}&= \dfrac{\text{change in height}}{\text{starting height}}\\\\
&=\dfrac{10\text{ inches}}{40\text{ inches}}\\\\
&=\dfrac{\cancel{10}\cancel{\text{ inches}}}{(4\times\cancel{10})\cancel{\text{ inches}}} \\\\
&=\dfrac14\\\\
&=0.25\\\\
&=25\%
\end{align}$

**David's height increased by $25\%$ from his fourth birthday to his eighth birthday.**

question.content:
![A graph plots David's height in inches versus age in years. The graph starts at (4, 40) and rises through the points (5, 42), (6, 48), (7, 48.5), and (8, 50) to (9, 58).](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/53b44c3675ce737133ce4d4db5f4d27e9b4fd3d2)

David’s mother recorded his height on six consecutive birthdays. The results are shown on the graph above. From his fourth birthday to his eighth birthday, David’s height increased by what percent?

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: $10$ is the amount by which David's height increased in inches, not the percent increase from his starting height of $40$ inches.
To determine the percent increase in height, the growth of $10$ inches should be compared to the starting height of $40$ inches, not the ending height of $50$ inches.
$25\%$ of $40$ inches is equal to $0.25\times 40=10$ inches, which is the height by which David grew from his fourth birthday to his eighth birthday.

$30\%$ of $40$ inches is equal to $0.3\times 40=12$ inches.

From his fourth birthday to his eighth birthday, David grew $10$ inches, not $12$.

$35\%$ of $40$ inches is equal to $0.35\times 40=14$ inches.

From his fourth birthday to his eighth birthday, David grew $10$ inches, not $14$.

hints.content:
Since we know $\blueD{x+z}=\blueD{15}$ and $\greenD{w+y}=\greenD{10}$, we can rewrite $(3w+3y)(2x+2z)$ in terms of $\blueD{x+z}$ and $\greenD{w+y}$, then evaluate the expression.

$\begin{align}
(3w+3y)(2x+2z)&=3(\greenD{w+y})\times2(\blueD{x+z}) \\\\
&=(3)(\greenD{10})\times2(\blueD{15}) \\\\
&=30\times30 \\\\
&=900
\end{align}$

**The value of $(3w+3y)(2x+2z)$ is $900$.**

question.content:
If $x+z=15$ and $w+y=10$, what is the value of $(3w+3y)(2x+2z)$ ?

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
We can answer this question by examining how the median and the range changes as a distribution changes. 

We can make up a list of measurements with a median of $\blueD{18}$ and a range of $\greenD{6}$. 

Many different lists of measurements can have a median of $\blueD{18}$ and a range of $\greenD{5}$. One example is:

$\greenD{15}$, $~15$, $~15$, $~15$, $~15$, $~15$, $~15$, $~\blueD{18}$, $~20$, $~20$, $~20$, $~20$, $~20$, $~20$, $~\greenD{20}$

If we subtract $3$ from each measurement, the new list will be:

$\greenD{12}$, $~12$, $~12$, $~12$, $~12$, $~12$, $~12$, $~\blueD{15}$, $~17$, $~17$, $~17$, $~17$, $~17$, $~17$, $~\greenD{17}$

The median of the new list will be $\blueD{15}$, and the range will be $\greenD{17}-\greenD{12}=\greenD{5}$.

**Top tip: Understand changes to lists**

When all values in a list are changed by the same amount, the range will remain the same, but the median will change by that amount.

**The median will decrease, but the range will stay the same.**

question.content:
The median and range of $15$ measurements are $18$ and $5$, respectively. If $3$ is subtracted from each of the $15$ measurements, which of the following statements regarding the median and range of the modified $15$ measurements must be true?

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: The difference between the maximum and minimum measurements won't change.
choices.content: The median and range will both decrease.

choices.clue: $3$ will be subtracted from all measurements, including the median measurement.
choices.content: The median and the range will both stay the same.

choices.clue: $3$ will be subtracted from all measurements, including the median measurement. The difference between the maximum and minimum measurements won't change.
choices.content: The median will stay the same, but the range will decrease.

choices.clue: $3$ will be subtracted from all measurements, including the median measurement. The difference between the maximum and minimum measurements won't change.
choices.content: The median will stay the same, but the range will increase.

choices.clue: $3$ will be subtracted from all measurements, including the median measurement. The difference between the maximum and minimum measurements won't change.
choices.content: The median will decrease, but the range will stay the same.

hints.content:
Based on the verbal description, we can create a reverse procedure that, when applied to the result, gives us the initial positive integer.

We can summarize the forward procedure as follows:

|| Forward Procedure ||
Step | Operator | Number
:-: | :-: | :-:
$\greenD{1\text{st}}$ | $\blueD{\text{multiply}}$ | $\greenD{5}$   
$\purpleC{2\text{nd}}$ | $\blueD{\text{subtract}}$ | $\purpleC{4}$   
$\maroonD{3\text{rd}}$ | $\blueD{\text{divide}}$ | $\maroonD{7}$   

To write the reverse procedure, we must write an inverse operation for each forward operation. An inverse operation undoes the forward operation. When writing inverse operations, the $\blueD{\text{operators}}$ change, but the numbers do not.

* $\blueD{\text{Addition}}$ undoes $\blueD{\text{subtraction}}$ and vice versa.
* $\blueD{\text{Multiplication}}$ undoes $\blueD{\text{division}}$ and vice versa.

Since we are reversing the procedure, we will also be performing the inverse operations in reverse order.

We can summarize the reverse procedure as follows:

|| Reverse Procedure ||
Step | Operator | Number
:-: | :-: | :-:
$\maroonD{1\text{st}}$ | $\blueD{\text{multiply}}$ | $\maroonD{7}$   
$\purpleC{2\text{nd}}$ | $\blueD{\text{add}}$ | $\purpleC{4}$   
$\greenD{3\text{rd}}$ | $\blueD{\text{divide}}$ | $\greenD{5}$ 

In words, the reverse procedure is:

* Multiply the final number by $7$
* Add $4$
* Divide by $5$

**The following sequential steps would reverse the procedure: **

* **Multiply the final number by $7$, add $4$, and divide by $5$.**

question.content:
A positive integer is multiplied by $5$; then $4$ is subtracted from the result, and that result is divided by $7$. Which of the following sequential steps would reverse that procedure?

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue:
The last step of the procedure is *divide* by $7$.

Therefore, the first step of the reversal should be *multiply* (the final number) by $7$.
choices.content: Divide the final number by $7$, add $4$, and multiply by $5$.

choices.clue:
The last step of the procedure is *divide* by $7$.

Therefore, the first step of the reversal should be *multiply* (the final number) by $7$.
choices.content: Divide the final number by $7$, subtract $4$, and multiply by $5$.

choices.clue:
The second to last step of the procedure is *subtract* $4$. 

Therefore, the second step of the reversal should be *add* $4$.
choices.content: Multiply the final number by $7$, subtract $4$, and divide by $5$.

choices.clue:
The first step of the procedure is *multiply* by $5$.

 Therefore, the last step of the reversal should be *divide* by $5$.
choices.content: Multiply the final number by $7$, add $4$, and multiply by $5$.

choices.clue: This choice correctly reverses the procedure.
choices.content: Multiply the final number by $7$, add $4$, and divide by $5$.

hints.content:
We can solve this question by first substituting the value of $x =2$ into the equation, then solving for $y$ by combining like terms and isolating $y$.

First, let's substitute $x=2$ into the equation.

$\begin{align}
3x-\dfrac32 y &=18 \\\\
3(2) -\dfrac32 y &=18 \\\\
6-\dfrac32 y &=18
\end{align}$

Now, we can solve for $y$:

$\begin{align}
6-\dfrac{3}{2}y &= 18 \\\\
6-\dfrac{3}{2}y \blueD{-6} &= 18 \blueD{-6} \\\\
-\dfrac{3}{2}y &= 12 \\\\
-\dfrac{3}{2}y \blueD{\times-\dfrac{2}{3}}&= 12 \blueD{\times-\dfrac{2}{3}}\\\\
y &= -8
\end{align}$

**Another approach:** we can also test the choices and see which value of $y$ satisfies the equation.  When using this backsolving strategy, it's best to start with the middle value and then move to a smaller or larger value if this choice is not correct.

Starting with choice (C):  

$\begin{align}
3(2)-\dfrac{3}{2}(-4) &\stackrel{?}= 18 \\\\
6+6 &\stackrel{?}= 18 \\\\
12 &\neq 18
\end{align}$

$y=-4$ does not satisfy the equation.

Let's try choice (B):

$\begin{align}
3(2)-\dfrac{3}{2}(-8) &\stackrel{?}= 18 \\\\
6+12 &\stackrel{?}= 18 \\\\
18 &\stackrel{\checkmark}=  18
\end{align}$

$y=-8$ satisfies the equation.

**$-8$ is the value of $y$.**

question.content:
If $3x-\dfrac32 y=18$ and $x=2$, what is the value of $y$ ?

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: This choice is equal to $x-18$.

Substituting $x=2$ into the equation gives us $6-\dfrac{3}{2}y=18$.

$\begin{align}
6-\dfrac{3}{2}y &= 18 \\\\
-\dfrac{3}{2}y &= 12 \\\\
y &= -8
\end{align}$
This choice is equal to $\dfrac{y}{2}$.
This choice is equal to $x$.
This choice could be the result of neglecting the negative sign in the coefficient of $y$.

hints.content:
We must use the line of best fit to find the point corresponding to an $x$-value of $4$.

![The line of best fit is at y = 2 when x = 4.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/f53abdd774718e90966caa88f823377ab57c611c)

The coordinates of the point are approximately $\greenD{(4,2)}$.

**$2$ is the best estimate of $y$ when $x=4$.**

question.content:
![The line of best fit for a scatterplot falls through estimated points (0.5, 7), (2.5, 4), and (4, 2).](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/c9378f3beecf91ac0713693e7f7164b5f77b82b5)


A scatterplot and its line of best fit are shown in the $xy$-plane above.  Based on the line of best fit, which of the following is the best estimate of $y$ when $x=4$ ?

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: $(4, 1.5)$ isn't on the line of best fit.
$(4, 2)$ is on the line of best fit.
$(4, 2.5)$ isn't on the line of best fit.
$(4, 3)$ isn't on the line of best fit.
$(4, 3.5)$ isn't on the line of best fit.

hints.content:
We can solve this question by creating a specific example to test each piece of information to determine whether we can calculate the number of women in the tournament.

**Note:** you must select *all* correct answers for your response to be marked correct!

Choice (A): *The ratio of the number of men in the tournament to the number of women in the tournament.*

 * If the ratio of men to women were $3$ to $1$, then $\dfrac{1}{3+1}=\dfrac{1}{4}$ of the people would be women.

* $\dfrac14 \times160= 40$ women

* This piece of information is $\greenD{\text{sufficient}}$.

Choice (B): *The percent of people in the tournament who are men.*
  
 * If $80\%$ of people were men, then $20\%$ would be women. 

 * $0.2\times160=32$ women

* This piece of information is $\greenD{\text{sufficient}}$.

Choice (C): *The difference between the number of men in the tournament and the number of women in the tournament).*  

  * If there were $40$ more men than women at the tournament, the number of women ($w$) can be calculated using the equation $w+(w+40)=160$.

* Solving $2w+40=160$ gives us $w=60$.

* This piece of information is $\greenD{\text{sufficient}}$.

**All three pieces of information are sufficient to determine the number of women in the tournament.**

question.content:
$$|$$
:-|:-:
There are a total of $160$ men and women in a golf tournament. If there are more men than women in the tournament, how many women are in the tournament?|

Which of the following individual pieces of information would be sufficient to answer the question in the problem above?


[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue:
For example, if the ratio of men to women were $3$ to $1$, then $\dfrac{1}{3+1}=\dfrac{1}{4}$ of the people would be women.

This is sufficient to determine how many women are in the tournament.
choices.content: The ratio of the number of men in the tournament to the number of women in the tournament

choices.clue:
For example, if $80\%$ of people were men, then $20\%$ would be women.

This is sufficient to determine how many women are in the tournament.
choices.content: The percent of people in the tournament who are men

choices.clue:
For example, if there were $40$ more men than women at the tournament, the number of women ($w$) can be calculated using the equation $w+(w+40)=160$.

This is sufficient to determine how many women are in the tournament.
choices.content: The difference between the number of men in the tournament and the number of women in the tournament

hints.content:
We can solve this question by calculating the total number of hours needed for the snow accumulation to equal the height of the action figure, then subtract the number of hours already elapsed, $4$.

After $4$ hours, the amount of snow accumulation is equal to $\dfrac{1}{3}$ the height of the action figure. This means the snow accumulation per hour is:

$\begin{align}
\dfrac{1}{3}\div4&=\dfrac{1}{3}\blueD{\times\dfrac{1}{4}} \\\\
&=\dfrac{1\times1}{3\times4} \\\\
&=\dfrac{1}{12}
\end{align}$

The rate of snow accumulation is equal to $\dfrac{1}{12}$ the height of the action figure per hour. This means the snow accumulation will be equal to the height of the action figure in $12$ hours because $\dfrac{1}{12}\times12=1$.

**Another approach:** since we need to multiply $\dfrac{1}{3}$ by $3$ to get $1$, the full height of the action figure, we also need to multiply $4$ by $3$ to get the total number of hours.

$4\times3=12$

But we're not done yet! The question asked for how many *more* hours. Since $4$ hours have already elapsed, the number of additional hours is:

$12-4=8$

**In $8$ __more__ hours, the amount of snow accumulation will be equal to the height of the action figure.**

question.content:
At the beginning of a snowstorm, Quinn placed an action figure outside to represent the amount of snow accumulation. After $4$ hours, the amount of snow accumulation is equal to $\dfrac{1}{3}$ the height of the action figure. At this rate, in how many __more__ hours will the amount of snow accumulation be equal to the height of the action figure?

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: In $4$ more hours, the snow accumulation will be equal to $\dfrac{2}{3}$ the height of the action figure.
In $6$ more hours, the snow accumulation will be equal to $\dfrac{5}{6}$ the height of the action figure.

In $12$ *total* hours from the beginning of the snowstorm, the snow accumulation will be equal to the height of the action figure.

$12-4=8$ more hours
In $9$ more hours, the snow accumulation will be equal to $\dfrac{13}{12}$ the height of the action figure.
In $12$ *total* hours from the beginning of the snowstorm, the snow accumulation will be equal to the height of the action figure.

hints.content:
We can show that the statement is false by finding a choice that satisfies the claim's condition, but not its conclusion.

* Condition: *$x$ is divisible by $y$.*

* Conclusion: *$x^2$ is divisible by $2y$.*

We can eliminate choices (B) and (E) because they don't satisfy the condition. Both $\dfrac{5}{4}$ and $\dfrac{8}{6}$ aren't whole numbers.

Next, let's check for a remaining choice where $x^2$ isn't divisible by $2y$.

Choice (A): $x=4$, $y=2$

* $\redD{\dfrac{4^2}{2\times2}=4}$.

Choice (C): $x=6$, $y=3$

* $\redD{\dfrac{6^2}{2\times3}=6}$.

Choice (D): $x=7$, $y=7$

* $\greenD{\dfrac{7^2}{2\times7}=3.5}$.

$x=7$, $y=7$ is a set of values for which the statement's conclusion isn't true.

**The following values of $x$ and $y$ can be used to show that Steve's claim is __not__ true:**

* $x=7$, $y=7$

question.content:
$$ | $$
:- | :-:
For positive integers $x$ and $y$, if $x$ is divisible by $y$, then $x^2$ is divisible by $2y$. |

Steve made the claim above. Which of the following values of $x$ and $y$ can be used to show that Steve's claim is __not__ true?

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: Since $\dfrac{4}{2}=2$ and $\dfrac{4^2}{2\times2}=4$, this choice supports rather than refutes the statement.
Since $5$ isn't divisible by $4$, this choice can't be used as a counterexample.
Since $\dfrac{6}{3}=2$ and $\dfrac{6^2}{2\times3}=6$, this choice supports rather than refutes the statement.
This choice satisfies the condition as $\dfrac{7}{7}=1$, but not the conclusion as $7^2$ is not divisible by $2\times7$.
Since $8$ isn't divisible by $6$, this choice can't be used as a counterexample.

hints.content:
For a triangle, the sum of interior angle measures is $180^\circ$. We can use this angle relationship to find the value of $x$.

First, we can use $\triangle ABC$ calculate the measure of angle $ABC$:

$\begin{align}
ABC+ACB+BAC&=180^\circ \\\\
ABC+70^\circ+60^\circ &= 180^\circ \\\\
ABC+70^\circ+60^\circ \blueD{-70^\circ-60^\circ} &= 180^\circ \blueD{-70^\circ-60^\circ}\\\\
ABC &= 50^\circ
\end{align}$

Angle $ABC$ is composed of angles $ABD$ and $CBD$. Since angles $ABD$ and $CBD$ have the same measure, their measure is $\dfrac{50^\circ}{2}=25^\circ$.

Now, we can use $\triangle ABD$ to calculate $x^\circ$, which is the measure of angle $ADB$:

$\begin{align}
ABD+ADB+BAD &= 180^\circ \\\\
25^\circ+ADB+60^\circ &= 180^\circ \\\\
25^\circ+ADB+60^\circ \blueD{-25^\circ-60^\circ} &= 180^\circ\blueD{-25^\circ-60^\circ} \\\\
ADB &= 95^\circ \\\\
x&=95
\end{align}$

**$95$ is the value of $x$.**

question.content:
![A figure consists of a triangle and a line segment. The line segment extends from vertex B of triangle A B C to point D on side A C. Angle B A D measures 60 degrees. Angle B D A measures x degrees. Angle B C D measures 70 degrees.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/a7cf56c3050967806983bb31a149c1d343cb69c5)

In the figure above, angle $ABD$ has the same measure as angle $CBD$. What is the value of $x$ ?

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: This is the measure, in degrees, of angle $ABC$.
This is the measure, in degrees, of angle $BDC$.

The measure of angle $ABD$ is $\dfrac{180^\circ-60^\circ-70^\circ}{2}=25^\circ$.

$x^\circ=180^\circ-60^\circ-25^\circ=95^\circ$
This is the sum of the measures, in degrees, of angles $BDC$ and $CBD$.
This is the sum of the measures, in degrees, of angles $ADB$ and $ABD$.
